channel.title: How To Guide on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!
channel.description: Recent content in How To Guide on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!

item.title: Ouvis ZV1 Camera Not Ready for Prime Time
item.description:
The Ouvis ZV1 camera is not ready for prime time. The only thing it’s good for is viewing the camera on your local network. You can’t view it remotely (no P2P viewing) and the FTP uploads don’t work so you can’t use it with Sensr.net.

The only thing good about this camera is that it’s pretty easy to setup. If you have the app, you can get the camera going pretty easily. You do need to plug it into an ethernet jack on the same network as your phone’s wifi, but once you do that, the Ouvis app can find the camera and configure it.

Useless FTP Config

Unlike other cameras like the Tenvis or the Foscam, there is no P2P functionality. This means you can’t watch the camera remotely unless you do some port forwarding magic. Here at Sensr.net we don’t like to do port forwarding, we prefer to have our cameras push rather than have to opening holes in a firewall.

Unfortunately the Ouvis ZV1 FTP doesn’t work. You can configure it but you can’t test it or use it. I have no idea what the FTP configuration does, maybe it sends the info back to China where they keep it for future use. Who knows. What they don’t do is allow you to upload images or videos to your own FTP server.

Doesn’t work with Sensr.net

To use Sensr.net you need to be able to FTP Jpeg images. Thus the Ouvis is useless when it comes to using Sensr.net or even viewing the camera remotely.

Give Tenvis a Try

Intead of the Ouvis I would recommend trying the Tenvis. The setup is easy, it supports P2P viewing, and it works with Sensr.net.

item.title: How to configure a Foscam FI9900P Outdoor Camera from Mac or Linux
item.description:
The Foscam FI9900P Outdoor HD Wireless Security Camera is a recent compact outdoor model from Foscam. It’s currently listing for around $125 on Amazon.

My biggest gripe with this camera is the mounting hardware. The camera can only be pointed forward and tilted up and down. There is no left or right articulation. In my case I was mounting the camera near the wall my garage. I had to put a little shim under one side of the mounting brack to get it to angle off to the side. See the image below for the final orientation. If I had mounted it straight ahead, I would have ended up with half the frame taken up by the left wall.

The camera works well with Sensr.net, so you can use our cloud DVR service with the Foscam. We have a free trial, so sign up and follow the instructions below on how to get it working with Sensr.net.

The camera is easy to setup using the Foscam app. The setup for this camera is pretty much the same as the Foscam R2 aka 1920tvl

Interesting Features in the Foscam App

The Foscam app seems to work. Sure, it’s filled with grammatical mistakes, but they will fix those over time. It let’s you share the images on WeChat and WeChat Moments, whatever that is. (Ok, it’s the Facebook Messenger of China, but not really very important to the non-Chinese market.)

It doesn’t have a selection for United States but you can select America, which is kind of the same thing.

Maybe the best new feature is that you can upgrade the firmware in the app! Excellent! Now when there is a security issue in the firmware, the app will make it simple to perform the upgrade.

What’s missing?

It has a lot of controls but it doesn’t have the local IP address for the camera. If you’re going to setup this camera for FTP you’ll need to find it’s IP address. Normally I would recommend connecting to your router and looking for the device with a matching MAC address. This will work if you’re using the wired connection. The MAC address is printed on the bottom of the camera. However, the wireless MAC address is not. It would be nice if the app would tell you the URL to connect to the web interface. If you’ve already put your amera on wifi, you can still find it but you may have to try connecting to a bunch of different IP addresses.

Port 88!

If you’re trying to connect to the camera, make sure to use port 88. For some reason the default port for Foscam is 88. That means you’ll have to go to http://IP:88/ to get to the web interface. For example, if your camera’s IP is 172.16.20.73 you’ll need to go to http://172.16.20.73:88/.

Safari Plugins!

If you’re using a Mac, you’ll need to install plugins. I really wish these camera manufacturers would just use web standards instead of making us install software. I tried configuring the camera without the plugins, but it really seems to enforce this. Maybe future versions of the app will support FTP configuration so we can skip the browser all together.

Configure the FTP Server

Log on to your account at Sensr.net and click the add camera button. This will give you the three pieces of information you need to configure your camera: server, username, and password. Our server names are f0.sensr.net through f9.sensr.net. The usernames are camNNN where NNN is an integer. The password is generated randomly. Be careful since in a password some characters can be confused. Zeros and Os looks alike. Ones and Ls also look alike. It’s best to copy and paste the passwords.

Once you have these, you can then go to the FTP sever page on the camera, which looks like this:

The FTP server URL shows a dir at the end. On the Sensr.net side we just ignore this. You can add it if you wish but it’s not needed. Your URL should start with FTP though, like this: ftp://fX.sensr.net/, where X is the server that Sensr.net tells you to use for your camera.

Configure Snapshot Settings

Next you’ll want to configure the snapshot settings, which tells the camera to upload JPEG snapshots to Sensr.net. We recommend you send an image per second to our servers. (See No Firewall Config for more details on why we recommend this.) This way we can generate a live Motion JPEG stream (MJPEG) on the Sensr.net site. Make sure to select all in the upper left hand corner of the schedule so the camera will always upload. If you don’t want us to process images on certain days or certain hours, this is the place to configure that. Make sure to click the Save button at the top. Once you’ve done this your Foscam should start uploading to Sensr.net.

On the Sensr.net side the page should go from this:

To a page that shows the image your camera uploaded.  Something like this:

Congratulations, now you’re done with the camera config. Your camera is now on Sensr.net. We’ll archive all the motion events, giving you 30 days of archives, SMS and email alerts, guest access, and a whole lot more.  You can view the live stream on our website or in our apps. No firewall configuration is needed. No PC in the basement required.

If you have any problems, send email to info @ sensr.net and we’ll try to help you out!

Don’t Set Scheduled Recording

You might be tempted to set the Scheduled Recording. This is for MKV video files. If you upload those to Sensr.net we’ll just remove them, since we only support JPEG files right now.

Don’t Set Motion Detection Settings

You also don’t need the motion detection settings to work with Sensr.net. We do the motion detection on the server side. See our blog post The True Meaning of Motion Detection Off for more details.

Summary

Generally I’m pretty happy with this camera. I didn’t put it outside but I think it would work well outdoors if you can get it connected to power. There is another more expensive model, the FI9901EP which supports POE (power over ethernet) so you can run just a single wire to the camera.

The good:

  • Pretty cheap at $125
  • Good image quality
  • Easy to setup
  • Works well with Sensr.net

The Bad:

  • Difficult to aim
  • Live view often fails
  • Missing IP address in app

If you want to learn more, check out this YouTube video that walks through the setup.

item.title: How to do port forwarding with eero
item.description:
The eero wifi system is really quite amazing. It lets you blanket your home in wifi and manage it with the eero app. You can do lots of neat things, like pause the internet for different devices or manage the network even when you’re not home.

Normally to do port forwarding to your IP camera, you need to configure the camera to have a specific IP address, then go to the router and add tell it to forward external ports to the internal ports on that IP address. eero takes a different approach.

However, if you don’t want to do port forwarding at all, you can simiply use Sensr.net and have your camera push to Sensr.net.

There are still some reasons you might want to do port forwarding, so here’s how it works with eero:

In the eero app, go to

Network Settings > Advanced Settings > Reservations & Port Forwarding

You’ll see a page that lets you add a reservation for your devices. Select the + Add a reservation menu. This will let you choose any of the devices currently connected to your network. In my case it was the Balcony Tenvis Camera which I wanted to expose on my network.

Once you make a reservation, you can then add port forwarding for that device. In my case I wanted to forward port 8080 on the outside to port 80 on my camera. This was so a friend of mine could experiment with my camera remotely. I also forwarded 554 and 660 and you can see in the screenshot below.

Why do port forwarding?

Generally you don’t wnat to do port forwarding if you don’t have to. If you want to see your camera outisde of your network, most cameras now come with apps that will allow you to view and configure your camera remotely without port forwarding. These cameras and apps are advertised as P2P enabled.

Of course you could also use Sensr.net which doesn’t require any port forwarding or special firewall configuration. You simply have the cameras push images to us. You can use Sensr.net without any firewall configuration at all.

Here’s that Tenvis balcony showing our view of Condado. This is not using any port forarding at all.

item.title: 5 Ways To Minimize IoT Vulnerabilities In Your Smart Home Network
item.description:
The Internet of Things (IoT) is continuing to expand and broaden its own horizons while simultaneously helping to usher people into a future, which is brimming with all the possibilities that an interconnected world presents. There are many industries that are working to incorporate the Internet of Things into their infrastructure. One of these industries has been the home security industry and there are many homeowners who are no proud parents to smart homes.

The smart home is one greatest aspects of the Internet of Things, just because of the sheer number of actions it allows you to complete through simple commands. For instance, some people can program their homes so that their lights come on as soon as they walk through the door. There are many benefits to the IoT, from increased efficiency to more comfortable living. However, there are some inherent vulnerabilities in the way the Internet of Things works, and it is easy to see why.

The basis of the IoT is that there are several different devices connected to each other on a network, and all sharing information and relaying data. This concept alone hints at the fact that there are multiple entryways for unauthorized users, as well as security concerns simply because of the sheer number of interconnected devices. When it comes to homeowners who are using the IoT to power their smart home networks, how can they minimize these IoT vulnerabilities? LetÕs take a look at some of the ways they can avert this:

1. Proper Password Management

It’s always best, to begin with, the basics, and one of the basics of great network security is always making sure that you are properly managing the passwords that grant devices access to your network. The first step to proper password management is to ensure that you create unique passwords for each of the devices that you have connected to your smart home network. In addition to this, it is best to make sure that you change these passwords on a regular basis so that you are consistently reducing the possibility of anyone discovering them. There are many homeowners who overlook this simple method, but it goes a long way to help keep your network secure.

2. Utilize a secure Firewall

It is important for homeowners to realize how vulnerable their networks can be if they do not provide any form of protection. One of the best forms of protection comes in the form of a secure firewall. It is not a smart idea to leave your network protected by a simple router. Homeowners should invest in secure firewalls that act as safeguards to every accessible endpoint that exists on their network. Firewalls exist to help protect your network from unauthorized access and they greatly reduce the chances of anyone successfully hacking into your smart home network.

3. Security Software Updates

Managing software updates is quite similar to proper password management. This is because the brunt of the responsibility falls on the homeowner to be attentive. It is important that you constantly check to see if there are software updates available for the devices that you have on your smart home network. These software updates are an important part of ensuring that your devices continue to run smoothly.

In some cases, manufacturers might have discovered a flaw in the device and then release a software patch meant to rectify said problem. If the user does not take advantage of these software patches, they will most likely end up having severe network flaws and holes that a hacker can take advantage of to gain access to their network. One of the best ways to manage security software updates is to set at least 3 monthly reminders. That way you never fall into the trap of forgetting that you need to update your security software.

4. Disable additional features

Now, this is something that many homeowners tend to overlook, simply because they do not know this might increase the chances of their network being made vulnerable. In most cases, smart devices have additional features that grant them access to the networks at different times without necessarily having to go through any security verification or authorization.

This process makes your entire network extremely vulnerable because it gives hackers the opportunity to exploit these loopholes. When you are setting up your smart home network, it is imperative that you identify the additional features that each device might use. If there are any that leave your network open and accessible, make sure that you disable these features. Essentially, you want to make it as hard as possible for a hacker to gain access to your network. The most efficient way to do this is to plug up all possible access points that could end up being taken advantage of.

5. Private Network

The Internet of Things is a network of interconnected devices. It is not really a shock that this might seem lucrative to hackers. However, an additional way to minimize the flaws of an IoT network in the smart home is to utilize private networks. The use of a private network will add an additional layer of security for your IoT devices. Also, it is always best to keep the network that functions with your IoT devices separate from other networks so that they do not compromise each other with the amount of data that is being transmitted.

Conclusion

The IoT on a smart home network really changes the way a home can operate, and it increases the amount of possible things that any homeowner can accomplish. The benefits of the IoT are very likely endless, as we are only just scratching the surface. However, there are some vulnerabilities that exist, much like anything else, so it is crucial for homeowners to make sure that they are safe guarding themselves against any of these vulnerabilities. You may think that this is a high level of paranoia, but it is important to remember that if someone is able to gain access to one device on an IoT network, they will most likely gain access to your entire network simply by piggybacking off of the compromised device.

The steps mentioned above will help keep your smart home network safe, but do not forget that physical security also plays an important role in stemming inherent network vulnerabilities. As a homeowner, make sure that you discuss your home security with a security professional or a residential locksmith, they will be able to help you with smart lock installations as well as help you keep your home safe and secure.

Author Bio

Ralph Goodman is a professional writer and the resident expert on locks and security over at the Lock Blog. The Lock Blog is a great resource to learn about keys, locks and safety. They offer tips, advice and how-to’s for consumers, locksmiths, and security professionals.

item.title: Alfa R36 AWUS036NH Network Scan Not Working
item.description:
Are you having problems with your Alfa R36 not being able to scan for networks? If the firmware version on your R36 needs to be at least 1.2.1.2 or it won’t work with the AWUS036NH. See the screen shot above. At first I didn’t realize that I had a different version of the AWUS036NH, the version that has an H at the end: AWUS036NH not AWUS036N. They are different.

After the firmware upgrade everything works great.

Get the firmware here.

What is this for?

Alfa R36 and AWUS036NH

You can use the R36 and the AWUS036NH to create your own hotspot out of another wifi network. The AWUS036NH is essentially an antennae. The R36 is a router that also creates it’s own wifi network. Let’s say you have a bunch of devices in your RV or boat. You can connect them all to the R36’s wifi network. Then when you park in the Starbucks parking lot, you can tell the R36 to use the Starbucks wifi and all of your devices on your local network will connect to the world on over the Starbucks network. You could have security cameras and laptops and wireless printers all connected to your R36. Thus you’ll have to scan for networks whenever you change locations, but at least you won’t need to

Once you have yours working, you might want to check out this article on optimizing your R36.

Record your IP camera on Sensr.net

Once you get your R36 working, go get some security cameras and connect them to Sensr.net!

item.title: FTP Setup on the Foscam Wireless Security Camera 1920TVL
item.description:
Foscam R2 2MP 1080P HD Wireless Security Camera

The Foscam Wireless Security Camera 1920TVL is the latest slim model from Foscam, also called the R2 it seems. I just opened this one yesterday and Foscam seems to be upping their game. The box is much nicer than they used in the previous models. It’s a bit more like the Apple experience. Not bad for a $70 product!

The camera works well with Sensr.net, so you can use our cloud DVR service with the Foscam. We have a free trial, so sign up and follow the instructions below on how to get it working with Sensr.net.

It speaks!

The camera is easy to setup using the Foscam app. As a nice bonus they have added audio cues that come from the camera. It says “Hello Foscam” when it powers up. Its little head rotates around and the camera said “Ethernet connection succeeded”. Later after I setup the wifi, it said “Wireless connection succeeded”. I have to admit this is a nice feature. No more wondering if the camera connected to the network or not. I’m not sure I want the audio piping up when the power goes off and back on though.

Interesting Features in the Foscam App

The Foscam app mostly seems to work. Sure, it’s filled with grammatical mistakes. It let’s you share the images on WeChat and WeChat Moments, whatever that is. (Ok, it’s the Facebook Messenger of China, but not really very important to the non-Chinese market.)

It doesn’t have a selection for United States but you can select America which is kind of cute. I’m pretty sure they mean France not French, but maybe it’s a language selector as well as a location selector?

Maybe the best new feature is that you can upgrade the firmware in the app! Excellent! Now when there is a security issue in the firmware, the app will make it simple to perform the upgrade.

What’s missing?

The Foscam R2 2MP 1080P HD Wireless Security Camera has a lot of controls but it doesn’t have the local IP address for the camera. If you’re going to setup this camera for FTP you’ll need to find it’s IP address. Normally I would recommend connecting to your router and looking for the device with a matching MAC address. This will work if you’re using the wired connection. The MAC address is printed on the bottom of the camera. However, the wireless MAC address is not. It would be nice if the app would tell you the URL to connect to the web interface. If you’ve already put your amera on wifi, you can still find it but you may have to try connecting to a bunch of different IP addresses.

Port 88!

If you’re trying to connect to the camera, make sure to use port 88. For some reason the default port for Foscam is 88. That means you’ll have to go to http://IP:88/ to get to the web interface. For example, if your camera’s IP is 172.16.20.73 you’ll need to go to http://172.16.20.73:88/.

Safari Plugins!

If you’re using a Mac, you’ll need to install plugins. I really wish these camera manufacturers would just use web standards instead of making us install software. I tried configuring the camera without the plugins, but it really seems to enforce this. Maybe future versions of the app will support FTP configuration so we can skip the browser all together.

Configure the FTP Server

Log on to your account at Sensr.net and click the add camera button. This will give you the three pieces of information you need to configure your camera: server, username, and password. Our server names are f0.sensr.net through f9.sensr.net. The usernames are camNNN where NNN is an integer. The password is generated randomly. Be careful since in a password some characters can be confused. Zeros and Os looks alike. Ones and Ls also look alike. It’s best to copy and paste the passwords.

Once you have these, you can then go to the FTP sever page on the camera, which looks like this:

The FTP server URL shows a dir at the end. On the Sensr.net side we just ignore this. You can add it if you wish but it’s not needed. Your URL should start with FTP though, like this: ftp://fX.sensr.net/, where X is the server that Sensr.net tells you to use for your camera.

Configure Snapshot Settings

Next you’ll want to configure the snapshot settings, which tells the camera to upload JPEG snapshots to Sensr.net. We recommend you send an image per second to our servers. (See No Firewall Config for more details on why we recommend this.) This way we can generate a live Motion JPEG stream (MJPEG) on the Sensr.net site. Make sure to select all in the upper left hand corner of the schedule so the camera will always upload. If you don’t want us to process images on certain days or certain hours, this is the place to configure that. Make sure to click the Save button at the top. Once you’ve done this your Foscam should start uploading to Sensr.net.

On the Sensr.net side the page should go from this:

To a page that shows the image your camera uploaded.  Something like this:

Congratulations, now you’re done with the camera config. Your camera is now on Sensr.net. We’ll archive all the motion events, giving you 30 days of archives, SMS and email alerts, guest access, and a whole lot more.  You can view the live stream on our website or in our apps. No firewall configuration is needed. No PC in the basement required.

If you have any problems, send email to info @ sensr.net and we’ll try to help you out!

Don’t Set Scheduled Recording

You might be tempted to set the Scheduled Recording. This is for MKV video files. If you upload those to Sensr.net we’ll just remove them, since we only support JPEG files right now.

Don’t Set Motion Detection Settings

You also don’t need the motion detection settings to work with Sensr.net. We do the motion detection on the server side. See our blog post The True Meaning of Motion Detection Off for more details.

Shodan Fun

The built in web server seems to be lighttpd.

Here are the headers:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: text/html
Accept-Ranges: bytes
ETag: "18210424"
Last-Modified: Thu, 28 Jul 2016 03:47:34 GMT
Content-Length: 38561
Date: Thu, 01 Dec 2016 12:08:20 GMT
Server: lighttpd/1.4.31

Scan on shodan.io for the etag finds a few cameras…

item.title: Legally Monitor your Airbnb with cheap Sensr.net security cameras
item.description:
We’ve been renting our place on Airbnb for about a year now and it’s been great to have Sensr.net cameras monitoring our place while we aren’t there. Don’t get me wrong, we don’t have cameras inside the private spaces of our home, we have exterior cameras that monitor the approaches to the house. Think Driveway Camera and Front Door Camera, etc. We only monitor the public spaces around our home, with one exception: owner only spaces.

Don’t Go There

When we rent our home on Airbnb we close off a handful of rooms, like the home office, garage, and basement storage rooms. We do have cameras in these spaces, where we don’t allow the Airbnb guest to go. These cameras are behind locked doors and should never record the guests unless they have picked the locks to get into the rooms.

Party Zone

External cameras are great in letting you know when or if the guest arrived and if the correct number of guests arrived. Our home has a strict ‘no parties’ rule. We have found this violated a couple of times and it was obvious from the cameras that more than the max 8 guests were staying at the home.

Neighbor Friendly

We share a driveway with our neighbors, and we make it very clear to our Airbnb guests that they are not to use the driveway.  This didn’t really work the first few times, but after we added You will be fined for using the driveway to the directions with an additional The driveway is monitor by security cameras this problem went away.

External Cameras

Adding external cameras can be more difficult than adding an internal wifi camera.  There are lots of great solutions, and if you can run a wire to the location where you want the camera, a POE (Power Over Ethernet) camera can be a great solution.  You only need to run one wire but you need a special router that can also send power.  If you live in a temperate climate, you might try this cheap camera cover solution.

Internal Cameras

Internal cameras are pretty easy to setup and there are thousands of models to choose from.  Generally these are cheap and work with your wifi.  You only need a power outlet and access to your wifi.  Lately I’ve been using Tenvis PTZ (pan, tilt, zoom) cameras.  I use their live viewing app to view the camera and change it’s positioning.  I use Sensr.net for recording, alerts, and sharing.

Share the Fun

We have a friend who keeps an eye on our home when we aren’t around.  With Sensr.net it’s easy to give him access to the exterior cameras.  When you have a camera on Sensr.net, you can give other’s guest access to those cameras.  He helps out when we’re not around and manages the cleaning crew.

Cost Effective

With Sensr.net you can use almost any camera.  If your camera can upload JPEG images with FTP (like 98% of all security cameras), then it will work with Sensr.net.  We don’t sell cameras, so we’re _camera agnostic.  _You could even make your own camera with a Raspberry Pi and a USB cam and it would work with Sensr.net.

Get Notified

With Sensr.net not only do we record in the cloud, but we can send you alerts when we detect motion.  This works great for the owner only spaces.  If you have a camera setup in your private space, you’ll appreciate a SMS or email when something starts moving around in there!

Free Trial!

If you’re an Airbnb host, you can give this a try for free.  If you’re not an Airbnb host, you can try it out too!  We have a one week free trial.  Grab a camera and give it a try.

Warning: setting up an IP camera can be a bit complex.  If you’re comfortable setting up a wifi router, then you’ll probably be fine.  One big advantage to using Sensr.net is that you don’t need to do any port forwarding or complex firewall rules, so it’s a bit easier than you might expect if you’ve tried this kind of thing in the past.  If you get stuck, just drop us an email at support@sensr.net and we’ll give you a hand.

item.title: Security Camera Archiving and Clip Download
item.description:
With your Sensr.net account,  we save images for one month on our site. Images are deleted when they are 32 days old. If you want to keep the images longer just save them as favorites or make a clip. Favorites and clips are kept until you delete the camera from our service.

If you make a clip, we will generate an mpeg file and send you a link to download it. The link we send is good for 30 days.  Make sure your login email is correct and check your spam folder if you don’t see the email.

We’re working on some programs that will allow you to pull down images to your local hard drive. See the open source project here.  If you’re a coder, give it a try.

https://github.com/adamb/Sensr-utils

item.title: Como Configurar a Gravação da D-Link DCS-5010L com FTP
item.description:
D-Link 5010L

A câmera D-Link DCS 5010L é um dos modelos mais populares da D-Link com visão noturna, rotação horizontal e vertical, WiFi e funciona com o serviço MyDlink. O valor da DCS-5010L é também muito acessível: atualmente ela custa $75 na Amazon. Esta câmera é muito parecida com a DCS-5020L, mas custa quase metade do preço.

Necessidade de Gravação

Apesar do serviço MyDlink permitir que você veja essa câmera remotamente, ele não suporta nenhum tipo de gravação ou armazenamento de imagens. É aqui que o Sensr.net entra. Nosso serviço permite armazenar automaticamente as imagens captadas no último mês. Este artigo vai ajudar você a configurar sua câmera DCS-5010L para que você veja tudo o que se passa com as suas coisas enquanto você não está olhando!

Também vou mostrar como configurar a câmera para enviar imagens para o site do Sensr.net, para que você tire partido de todas as funcionalidades do nosso serviço, como o armazenamento, o compartilhamento, e os alertas.

Resumo

  1. Configure o seu serviço MyDlink
  2. Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net
  3. Apresente o Sensr.net à sua câmera

Detalhes

Passo 1: Para configurar a câmera, utilize o CD e as instruções disponibilizados em conjunto com a câmera. Tudo o que você precisa de fazer é conectar a câmera ao seu roteador e correr o software do CD. Você vai acabar por criar uma conta no site do MyDlink que vai dar acesso à sua câmera a partir do site ou dos aplicativos MyDlink. Após este passo, você conseguirá acessar sua câmera e alterar suas configurações. A página de configuração de sua câmera vai ter mais ou menos esse aspeto:

Página Admin DCS-5010L

Agora você já consegue fazer alterações às configurações da câmera através do seu navegador. Se o que você pretende é assistir às filmagens em tempo real a partir de sua casa ou através do site MyDlink, então não será necessário fazer mais nada. (Existem outras configurações, como conexão sem fios e tamanho da imagem, que você pode alterar diretamente na interface, mas que eu não vou abordar nesse artigo.)

Adicione uma nova câmera à sua conta Sensr.net

Passo 2: Faça o login no Sensr.net, utilizando o seu email e a sua senha. Se ainda não possui uma conta, você pode criar uma gratuitamente na página de inscrição. Depois de fazer login, clique no botão verde Add Camera.

Clique no botão verde

Na página seguinte, você vai poder escolher o título (ou nome) da câmera, o fuso horário, a privacidade e o modelo. O título deve descrever o que a câmera está filmando. O título mais popular no Sensr.net é Porta da Frente, que nos dá uma ideia de como os usuários utilizam o nosso site. Apesar de nós gerarmos um nome genérico para sua câmera baseado no login, você pode dar qualquer nome à sua câmera. O fuso horário é muito importante. Ele é utilizado para determinar a vista diária dos arquivos. Por padrão, as câmeras são privadas, o que significa que apenas você tem acesso a elas. Se quiser que sua câmera seja pública, você pode alterar essa configuração aqui. O modelo da câmera apenas indica qual o modelo que está sendo configurado. Nesse caso, o modelo é DCS-5010L.

Dê um nome à sua câmera e compartilhe alguns detalhes

Depois de preencher todos os detalhes e clicar no link Next Step, nós vamos criar algumas credenciais FTP para você. Será necessário introduzir esses dados na sua câmera no próximo passo. Os dados com mais importância são:

  1. Servidor FTP
  2. Nome de usuário
  3. Senha

Mantenha essa janela aberta ou copie os dados, uma vez que você vai precisar deles em breve. Você pode recuperar esses dados, a qualquer momento, na página de detalhes da câmera.

Credenciais FTP

Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net

Passo 3: Agora é necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net. Volte à página da DCS-5010L, fazendo o login no site MyDlink e clicando no link de configuração. Clique em “SETUP” no menu superior e, depois, em “FTP”, na lateral. Você vai ser encaminhado para essa página:

Página Configuração FTP DCS-5010L

As setas vermelhas mostram os parâmetros que devem ser configurados. No campo Host Name, introduza o servidor FTP que fornecemos na página “Add Camera” no Sensr.net. Copie também o usuário e a senha. Escolha “Passive Mode”, uma vez que o Sensr.net suporta apenas o modo FTP passivo.

É também necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net periodicamente. Para isso, selecione “Enable uploading to the FTP server” e confirme que “Always” e “1 Frames/Second” estão também selecionados. Estas são as configurações padrão e funcionam bem com o Sensr.net. As configurações padrão para o nome do ficheiro também são bem suportadas pelo serviço, por isso não existe necessidade de alterar.

Não se esqueça de clicar no botão “Save Settings” localizado no topo da página. Após realizar este passo, a sua câmera DCS-5010L já estará enviando imagens para o Sensr.net.

Agora a configuração está terminada. Pode fechar a janela do navegador que mostra as configurações de sua câmera e voltar para o Sensr.net. Clique no botão Next Step para ver as imagens enviadas pela sua câmera. Você verá uma página assim:

Sucesso!

Agora que a sua câmera já está configurada, existem outras coisas que você pode fazer:

  • Adicionar alertas de movimento por SMS ou email
  • Convidar outros usuários para ver a sua câmera
  • Incorporar o streaming de vídeo em tempo real no seu blog ou outro site
  • Criar um clipe de vídeo e compartilhar no Facebook, Twitter ou YouTube

Se tiver alguma dificuldade ou pergunta, clique no botão de Feedback no lado direito de qualquer uma das páginas do Sensr.net e coloque a sua questão. Geralmente, nós nos esforçamos por responder no prazo máximo de 24h horas.

item.title: Como Configurar a Gravação da D-Link DCS-5020L com Uploads FTP
item.description:
DCS-5020L da D-Link

A câmera D-Link DCS 5020L é um dos modelos mais populares da D-Link. Ela dispõe de visão noturna, rotação horizontal e vertical, WiFi e funciona com o serviço MyDlink. O valor da DCS 5020L é também muito acessível: atualmente ela custa $135 na Amazon.

Necessidade de Gravação

Apesar do serviço MyDlink permitir que você assista às filmagens da câmera remotamente, ele não suporta nenhum tipo de gravação ou armazenamento de imagens. É aqui que o Sensr.net entra. Nosso serviço permite armazenar automaticamente as imagens captadas no último mês. Este artigo vai ajudar você a configurar sua câmera DCS-5020L para que você veja tudo o que se passa com as suas coisas enquanto você não está olhando!

Também vou mostrar como configurar a câmera para enviar imagens para o site do

Sensr.net, para que você tire partido de todas as funcionalidades do nosso serviço, como o armazenamento, o compartilhamento, e os alertas.

Resumo

  1. Configure o seu serviço MyDlink
  2. Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net
  3. Apresente o Sensr.net à sua câmera

Detalhes

Passo 1: Para configurar a câmera, utilize o CD e as instruções disponibilizados em conjunto com o aparelho. Tudo o que você precisa de fazer é conectar a câmera ao seu roteador e correr o software do CD. Você vai acabar por criar uma conta no site do MyDlink que vai dar acesso à sua câmera a partir do site ou dos aplicativos MyDlink. Após este passo, você conseguirá acessar sua câmera e alterar suas configurações. A página de configuração de sua câmera vai ter mais ou menos esse aspeto:

Página de Admin da DCS-930L

Agora você já consegue fazer alterações às configurações da câmera através do seu navegador. Se o que você pretende é assistir às filmagens em tempo real a partir de sua casa ou através do site MyDlink, então não será necessário fazer mais nada. (Existem outras configurações, como conexão sem fios e tamanho da imagem, que você pode alterar diretamente na interface, mas que eu não vou abordar nesse artigo.)

Adicione uma nova câmera à sua conta Sensr.net

Passo 2: Faça o login no Sensr.net, utilizando o seu email e a sua senha. Se ainda não possui uma conta, você pode criar uma gratuitamente na página de inscrição. Depois de fazer login, clique no botão verde Add Camera.

Clique no botão verde

Na página seguinte, você vai poder escolher o título (ou nome) da câmera, o fuso horário, a privacidade e o modelo. O título deve descrever o que a câmera está filmando. O título mais popular no Sensr.net é Porta da Frente, que nos dá uma ideia de como os usuários utilizam o nosso site. Apesar de nós gerarmos um nome genérico para sua câmera baseado no login, você pode dar qualquer nome à sua câmera. O fuso horário é muito importante. Ele é utilizado para determinar a vista diária dos arquivos. Por padrão, as câmeras são privadas, o que significa que apenas você tem acesso a elas. Se quiser que sua câmera seja pública, você pode alterar essa configuração aqui. O modelo da câmera apenas indica qual o modelo que está sendo configurado. Nesse caso, o modelo é DCS-5020L.

Dê um nome à sua câmera e compartilhe alguns detalhes

Depois de preencher todos os detalhes e clicar no link Next Step, nós vamos criar algumas credenciais FTP para você. Será necessário introduzir esses dados na sua câmera no próximo passo. Os dados com mais importância são:

  1. Servidor FTP
  2. Nome de usuário
  3. Senha

Mantenha essa janela aberta ou copie os dados, uma vez que você vai precisar deles em breve. Você pode recuperar esses dados, a qualquer momento, na página de detalhes da câmera.

Credenciais FTP

Apresente sua câmera ao Sensr.net

Passo 3: Agora é necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net. Volte à página da DCS-5020L, fazendo o login no site MyDlink e clicando no link de configuração. Clique em “SETUP” no menu superior e, depois, em “FTP”, na lateral. Você vai ser encaminhado para essa página:

DCS-5020L Página de configuração FTP

As setas vermelhas mostram os parâmetros que devem ser configurados. No campo Host Name, introduza o servidor FTP que fornecemos na página “Add Camera” no Sensr.net. Copie também o usuário e a senha. Escolha “Passive Mode”, uma vez que o Sensr.net suporta apenas o modo FTP passivo.

É também necessário configurar sua câmera para enviar imagens para o Sensr.net periodicamente. Para isso, selecione “Enable uploading to the FTP server” e confirme que “Always” e “1 Frames/Second” estão também selecionados. Estas são as configurações padrão e funcionam bem com o Sensr.net. As configurações padrão para o nome do ficheiro também são bem suportadas pelo serviço, por isso não existe necessidade de alterar.

Não se esqueça de clicar no botão “Save Settings” localizado no topo da página. Após realizar este passo, a sua câmera DCS-5020L já estará enviando imagens para o Sensr.net.

Agora a configuração está terminada. Pode fechar a janela do navegador que mostra as configurações de sua câmera e voltar para o Sensr.net. Clique no botão Next Step para ver as imagens enviadas pela sua câmera. Você verá uma página assim:

Sucesso!

Agora que a sua câmera já está configurada, existem outras coisas que você pode fazer:

  • Adicionar alertas de movimento por SMS ou email
  • Convidar outros usuários para ver a sua câmera
  • Incorporar o streaming de vídeo em tempo real no seu blog ou outro site
  • Criar um clipe de vídeo e compartilhar no Facebook, Twitter ou YouTube

Se tiver alguma dificuldade ou pergunta, clique no botão de Feedback no lado direito de qualquer uma das páginas do Sensr.net e coloque a sua questão. Nós tentaremos responder no prazo máximo de 24h horas.

Divirta-se!

item.title: Como configurar uma Foscam FI9821W V2 do Mac ou Linux
item.description:
A Foscam FI9821W V2 é uma das câmeras IP mais populares atualmente. O seu valor ronda os $150 na Amazon. As instruções incluem um software de configuração da câmera para Windows e Mac, mas ele não é realmente necessário. Nesse artigo, vou mostrar como configurar a câmera sem o software. Tenha em atenção que a porta padrão dessa câmera é a 88. Perdi 30 minutos para o perceber, e ainda mais tempo para entender o que isso significa.

Também vou mostrar como enviar imagens para o

Sensr.net, para que você possa tirar partido de todas as nossas funcionalidades, como 30 dias de armanezamento, sem configuração do firewall, compartilhamento de vídeos, streaming incorporável em tempo real, acesso compartilhado com lista de usuários convidados, etc.

Resumo

  1. Conecte a câmera ao seu roteador e ligue.
  2. No seu roteador, veja qual o endereço IP da câmera.
  3. Coloque o endereço IP da câmera no seu navegador e faça a sua configuração.
  4. Apresente a sua câmera ao Sensr.net.
  5. Apresente Sensr.net à sua câmera.

Detalhes

Estou assumindo que você conseguiu executar sem problemas o Passo 1.

Passo 2: Encontre o endereço de IP de seu roteador

Para executar o Passo 2, você necessita de fazer login no seu roteador. Você pode encontrar o endereço IP de seu roteador, consultando as configurações de seu computador. Num Mac você deve aceder a Network Settings > Advanced > TCP/IP. No meu MacBook Pro, com sistema operativo Lion, eu vejo isso:

No Linux, você pode correr o comando ifconfig para obter essa informação. No meu caso, esse comando indica que o meu roteador é 10.1.1.1. Uma configuração mais comum é 192.168.1.1, mas pode ser qualquer outra. Assim que você encontrar essa informação, aceda ao seu roteador inserindo http://10.1.1.1 na barra de endereços de seu navegador (ou o endereço que você encontrou na sua rede). O mais provável é que você tenha de se conectar ao seu roteador. Os roteadores são muito diferentes entre si, vou mostrar as páginas do meu Netgear WPN824.

Após efetuar o login no seu roteador, encontre a página que mostra todos os dispositivos conectados. Em baixo mostro a página de meu roteador, selecionei Attached Devices, à esquerda, e obtive essa lista.

Lista de dispositivos conectados

Para encontrar a sua câmera IP, você precisa de procurar o endereço MAC de sua câmera. (O endereço MAC está num adesivo na base da câmera). Como o endereço MAC de minha câmera acaba em 97, utilizei a pesquisa Chrome (CMD-F) e busquei por :97. O endereço IP nesse caso foi 10.1.1.26.

Passo 3: Direcione seu navegador para o endereço de IP da câmera e faça sua configuração

Para chegar à sua câmera, direcione seu navegador para o endereço IP que você encontrou. Nesse caso, http://10.1.1.26:88. Não se esqueça de incluir a porta :88, como indiquei no início do artigo.

Descobri que o Chrome, no Mac, não apresenta a página corretamente, mas o Safari consegue fazer um bom trabalho. Existem alguns plugins que você pode utilizar com o Chrome, mas é muito mais fácil usar o Safari.

Quando você acessa à página de sua câmera, ela terá esse aspeto.

Página de Configuração da FI9821W V2

No Safari, você pode clicar no separador de Live Video e ver a sua câmera. A partir dessa página você pode rodar a sua câmera horizontal e verticalmente e assistir ao vídeo por streaming em tempo real a partir de sua rede doméstica. Hoje, algumas árvores estão sendo cortadas lá fora, por isso decidi instalar a câmera para observar o processo. É assim que você vai ver o vídeo:

Vídeo em tempo real no Safari

Você pode ver na tela anterior que estou correndo a última versão de firmware, 10.11.1.18.

Atualize o Firmware para a versão 1.11.1.18 ou superior

A última versão de firmware é a ideal para que sua câmera trabalhe na perfeição com o Sensr.net. (Siga as instruções cuidadosamente. Se ainda não está correndo a versão 1.11.1.16, você precisa de fazer uma atualização para essa versão e só depois atualizar para a última versão 1.11.1.18. A minha câmera tinha a versão 1.11.1.15, por isso tive de fazer uma dupla atualização. A última versão de firmware pode ser encontrada aqui e o comunicado pode ser visto aqui.

Passo 4: Apresente a sua câmera ao Sensr.net

Adicione uma Câmera Nova à sua conta Sensr.net

Faça o login em sua conta Sensr.net e selecione Add Camera. Sensr.net tem um período de teste gratuito, por isso experimente e veja se é aquilo de que estava à procura. (Criar uma conta no Sensr.net. é gratuito. Após terminar o seu período de teste gratuito, o controlo da câmera custa desde $9.95/mês). Assim que você fizer o login, você vai ver uma página como essa:

Página para adicionar uma nova câmera

A seguir, você vai ver essa página, onde você pode definir o fuso horário para a sua câmera, atribuir um nome, e indicar-nos o modelo. Todas as câmeras ficam predefinidas como privadas, mas você pode alterar sua privacidade para pública se você quiser compartilhar as filmagens.

Passo 1

Após você realizar esses passos, nós vamos gerar credenciais FTP para a sua câmera. Isso vai gerar um login para a sua FI9821W V2 para onde pode ser feito o upload de imagens por FTP. Esse dado diz à sua câmera para onde deve ser feito o upload. Os dados com mais importância são:

  1. Servidor FTP
  2. Nome de usuário FTP
  3. Senha FTP

Guarde esses dados para que possamos incluí-los mais tarde.

Credenciais FTP

Passo 5: Apresente Sensr.net à sua câmera

Agora é necessário configurar a sua câmera para enviar imagens ao Sensr.net. Volte à página de configuração da câmera usando o endereço de IP que descobrimos anteriormente. Selecione Network e, depois, FTP Settings. A página apresentada será:

Configurar FTP

Introduza no primeiro campo o Servidor FTP da página de configuração do Sensr.net. Vai aparecer dessa forma ftp://f9.sensr.net/ ou qualquer outro servidor que o Sensr.net atribuiu à sua câmera. Atualmente os nossos servidores têm designação de f0.sensr.net a f9.sensr.net. Mantenha a porta 21 e o FTP mode como PASV. O nome de usuário é único para a sua câmera, por isso utilize o que foi atribuído pelo Sensr.net. O mesmo se aplica para a senha. O melhor é copiar e colar, para evitar erros no processo. Clique no botão de teste e a FI9821W vai verificar os dados de login. Se aparecer uma mensagem de Sucesso, o processo foi concluído. Caso contrário, verifique se os dados do servidor, nome de usuário e senha estão corretos.

Sugerimos que configure a câmera para enviar uma imagem por segundo. Assim, você vai conseguir ver a gravação em tempo real a partir do Sensr.net. Para isso, acesse a página Video/Snapshot Settings:

Configuração Vídeo > Snapshots

Aqui você pode adicionar 1 como intervalo para que a câmera faça o upload contínuo de um frame por segundo. Selecione também todos os intervalos de tempo para que a câmera faça o upload 24h por dia, 7 dias por semana. Para salvar as configurações, não se esqueça de clicar no botão Save, no topo. Assim que terminar esses passos, a sua câmera FI9821WV2 começará a fazer o upload para o Sensr.net.

No Sensr.net a página deve passar desse aspeto:

A aguardar o upload

Para uma página que mostra a imagem que sua câmera enviou. Algo como:

Sucesso!

Muitos parabéns, acabou a configuração de sua câmera. A sua câmera está agora ligada ao Sensr.net. Vamos arquivar todos os movimentos, disponibilizando 30 dias de arquivos, SMS e alertas de email, acesso livre à sua lista de convidados e muito mais. Você pode assistir em tempo real ao streaming de vídeo a partir de nosso site ou dos nossos aplicativos. Não é necessário configurar um firewall, nem ter um PC na cave para observar as imagens de sua câmera.

Se surgir alguma dificuldade, envie um email para info @ sensr.net e nós vamos tentar ajudar você!

item.title: How to setup the Panasonic BL-C30A Network Cam with Cloud Recording
item.description:
Despite looking like it belongs in the 90s the Panasonic BL-C30A actually boasts some great reviews. It is easy to setup and provides a pretty high quality video. It might not be the most sleek or attractive camera on the market but it will get the job done and its built by a very large and reputable company which is a plus for a lot of people. In this tutorial I will show you how to get this bad boy setup and streaming to the cloud with Sensr.net so you can watch your stuff from anywhere at anytime.

I’ve broken this tutorial up into steps to make it easier to follow:

  1. Setup your hardware
  2. Find your camera’s IP address and go to the network access page
  3. Go to Sensr.net and get FTP credentials
  4. Tell your camera about your new FTP credentials

Feel free to skip around if you are confident you can accomplish some setups without reading the tutorial.

Step one: Setup your hardware

I don’t know if this part even counts as a tutorial because my instructions are pretty simple: set your hardware. Seriously just plug that camera in. Plug it into your router and a wall outlet and you are done. Boom. That was fast. If you want your camera to connect using wireless just hold off on that for now and we can fix it later.

Step two: Find your camera’s IP address and go to the network access page

As always I suggest doing this by going through your router.

I will show you how to do this on a mac (because I am writing from a mac) but it is also very easy to do from a PC (the PC process is outlined in this article). On my mac it is under system preferences>Network>Advanced…>TCP/IP. The page looks like this:

Once you have the IP address just enter it into your browser and it should bring you to a network access page. Everyone’s looks different depending on the make and model of their browser. Mine, for example, looks like this:

If you aren’t sure which device is new you can always unplug your camera then plug it back in to see which one disappears and comes back.

Now that you’ve got the camera’s IP address just type it into your browser. There will be an authentication window with the username and password already. SAVE THOSE.  Now you should come to a page that looks like this:

First time on network access page

You might have to install a plug-in. Go ahead and do that and now you will have full access to the camera. Explore this page when you have time to find out what your camera can really do. For now it is onto step three.

Step three: Go to Sensr.net and get FTP credentials.

Now you are ready to setup stuff from the Sensr.net side of things. We will store all your recorded data in the cloud so you can access it from any device, anywhere. We have a number of different plans but the first week is always free so just set it up and give it a try. If you don’t like it you don’t need to continue to a payed plan. Log into your Sensr.net account click the Add Camera button. Once you login you’ll see a page like this: Next you’ll see a page like this where you can set the timezone for your camera, give it a name, and tell us the model.  Cameras default to private but you can make them public if you want to share them with the world. After that, we’ll generate some FTP credentials for your server. This generates a login for your  Panasonic to where it can upload images via FTP. This tells your camera where to upload the images. The important information here is:

  1. FTP Server
  2. FTP User name
  3. FTP Password

Save these so we can add them to your camera later. 

Now the last step…

Step four: Tell your camera about your new FTP credentials.

Go back to the network access page. Click on the setup tab then go to Buffer/Transfer. Click No and check enable Buffer/Transfer then choose timer for the trigger. Click next the choose always on the schedule page. Set the image resolution and quality as high as you like and choose one image per second on the next page. Choose FTP then Copy and Paste the credentials you got earlier. Make sure the port is set to 21 and the mode is set to passive. Hit save and you are done.

Go back to the Sensr.net tab and it should look like this:

Success!

Congratulations, now you’re done with the camera config. You’re camera is now on Sensr.net. We’ll archive all the motion events, giving you 30 days of archives, SMS and email alerts, guest access, and a whole lot more.  You can view the live stream on our website or in our apps.  No firewall configuration is needed.  No PC in the basement required.

If you have any problems, send email to info @ sensr.net and we’ll try to help you out!

item.title: How to setup the TRENDnet TV-IP311PI With Cloud Recording
item.description:
The TRENDnet TV-IP311PI network camera is a nice solution if you want an outdoor camera that supports Power Over Ethernet (POE). To get started with this camera on Sensr.net, just plug it into a POE router and it will grab an IP address via DHCP. To find the IP address, you can use the included software or just look at the attached devices on your router’s admin page. Look for the MAC address of the camera in the list and you’ll be good to go. In my case the camera was using 10.1.1.113.

I’ll also show you how to push images to Sensr.net so you can take advantage of all of our cool features, like SMS and email alerts, 30 days archiving, no firewall config, clip sharing, embedable live streams, guest access, etc.

Next point your browser at that IP address and it will ask you to login. The default login and password for the TV-IP311PI  is admin and admin.  You’ll probably want to change that.

To get this camera working with Sensr.net just have it upload to Sensr.net at 1 frame per second.  Here are the details…

Add a New Camera to your Sensr.net account

Simply log into your Sensr.net account click the Add Camera button. Sensr.net has a free one week trial, so give it a go and see if it works for you.  (It’s free to setup an account with Sensr.net. Camera monitoring starts at $9.95/month after your free trial is up.)  Once you login you’ll see a page like this:

Next you’ll see a page like this where you can set the timezone for your camera, give it a name, and tell us the model.  Cameras default to private but you can make them public if you want to share them with the world.

After that, we’ll generate some FTP credentials for your camera. This generates a login for your TRENDnet TV-IP311PI  to where it can upload images via FTP. This tells your camera where to upload the images. The important information here is:

  1. FTP Server
  2. FTP User name
  3. FTP Password

Save these so we can add them to your camera later.

 

Tell your camera about Sensr.net

Now you need to configure your camera so it will upload images to Sensr.net. Go back to the camera config page using the IP address we discovered above.  Get to the Snapshot settings page by clicking:

Advanced > Events > Snapshot

The Snapshot Settings. It will look like this.  You’ll want to set the camera to upload continuously, which TRENDnet calls CONTENTIOUS, but we’ll forgive them.  Note the upload interval is set to 1,000 milliseconds.  That’s the fastest upload the TRENDnet TV-IP311PI  will support, but 1 FPS is fine for use with Sensr.net.

Next we need to configure where those snapshots will be uploaded.  Go to the FTP Server page by clicking:

Advanced > Storage > FTP Server

The FTP Server page will look like this:

For some reason the TRENDnet camera won’t take a hostname, so we need to use an IP address.  To get the IP address for your server, you can use the command nslookup or just ping the address.  Currently we have two IP addresses per hostname.  For example, nslookup for f9.sensr.net will return:

$ nslookup f9.sensr.net
Server: 208.67.222.222
Address: 208.67.222.222#53
Non-authoritative answer:
Name: f9.sensr.net
Address: 96.126.101.33
Name: f9.sensr.net
Address: 74.207.245.42

This means we can use either 96.126.101.33 or 74.207.245.42 for the Server Address.  The drawback to this is your camera is tied to a specific server.  We occasionally reboot servers or take them offline for maintenance.  If the camera was connecting to a hostname, it would simply reconnect to another server.  So by using an IP address, the TRENDnet TV-IP311PI  isn’t as fault tolerant as it should be.

The port should stay 21. The username is unique to your camera so use whatever you got from Sensr.net’s add camera flow. Ditto for the password. Best to copy and paste it so you don’t make a mistake. You can leave the other options as they are.  We ignore them on our side.  Click the Save button and the TRENDnet TV-IP311PI  should start uploading to Sensr.net.

On the Sensr.net side the page should go from this:

To a page that shows the image your camera uploaded.  Something like this:

Congratulations, now you’re done with the camera config. You’re camera is now on Sensr.net. We’ll archive all the motion events, giving you 30 days of archives, SMS and email alerts, guest access, and a whole lot more.  You can view the live stream on our website or in our apps.  No firewall configuration is needed.  No PC in the basement required.

If you have any problems, send email to info @ sensr.net and we’ll try to help you out!

item.title: How to setup the Linksys Wireless-N Camera with Cloud recording
item.description:
Definitely good looking

The Linksys Wireless-N IP Cam is definitely in the more affordable range of IP cameras. It comes from a very reputable name, Linksys has been making electronics, since before I was born, and has plenty of great features not the least of which is FTP compatibility. It is important to note, however, that it does not support scheduled FTP uploads, only motion detection uploads. So you will not be able to get a “live view” on Sensr.net. This is pretty disappointing but that doesn’t mean that if you have this camera all is lost. Be warned that the reviews on amazon are a little harsh (it only got three stars over all), but, a lot of those reviews revolve around how difficult it is to set up so that won’t be a problem for you if you read and follow this tutorial!

This tutorial will follow these steps:

  1. Hardware setup and finding the camera’s IP address
  2. Navigating to the camera’s network access page
  3. Getting FTP credentials from Sensr.net
  4. Go to you camera and start cloud recording

Step: Hardware setup and finding the camera’s IP address

Hardware setup, as always, is the easiest part here. Just plug your camera into both your router and a standard wall outlet. Make sure you put it in an inconspicuous place with a good line of view. If you want to connect it wirelessly you will have to setup with a wired connection and then change it to a wireless connection once you finish setup.

Next you will need to find your camera’s IP address. There are two ways to do this: going through your router or going through the included software. The included software is very self explanatory and easy to follow so I will not include it in this tutorial instead I will focus on the other way.

I will show you how to do this on a mac (because I am writing from a mac) but it is also very easy to do from a PC (the PC process is outlined in this article). On my mac it is under system preferences>Network>Advanced…>TCP/IP. The page looks like this:

Once you have the IP address just enter it into your browser and it should bring you to a network access page. Everyone’s looks different depending on the make and model of their browser. Mine, for example, looks like this:

If you aren’t sure which device is new you can always unplug your camera then plug it back in to see which one disappears and comes back.

Step 2: Navigating to the Camera’s Network Access page

Type the IP address into your internet browser and you will come to a page asking you for a username and password. The defaults are admin and admin. Change these! Once you enter the username and password you will come to this page:

Sorry for the tiny picture.

From here you can control every aspect of your camera. Feel free to explore it when you have time.

Step three: Get FTP credentials from Sensr.net

Simply log into your Sensr.net account click the Add Camera button. Sensr.net has a free one week trial, so give it a go and see if it works for you.  (It’s free to setup an account with Sensr.net. Camera monitoring starts at $9.95/month after your free trial is up.)  Once you login you’ll see a page like this:

Next you’ll see a page like this where you can set the timezone for your camera, give it a name, and tell us the model.  Cameras default to private but you can make them public if you want to share them with the world.

After that, we’ll generate some FTP credentials for your camera. This generates a login for your Linksys Wireless-N IP Cam  to where it can upload images via FTP. This tells your camera where to upload the images. The important information here is:

  1. FTP Server
  2. FTP User name
  3. FTP Password

Save these so we can add them to your camera later.

 

Now onto the last step…

Step four: Go to you camera and start cloud recording

Go back to your camera’s Network Access page. This camera does not support constant recording to FTP which is a shame but you can have it send clips when motion is detected. Choose setup>motion detection then copy and paste in your FTP credentials, Make sure the motion detection box is checked and the mode is set to passive. Set the port to 21. Change the precapture to 4, the post capture to 5, and the interval to one.

Now you are done. You should be recording to Sensr.net. For now the firmware only lets your camera send clips to use when it detects motion but hopefully they will change that soon. For now explore all our features and the features of your camera. As always if you have any questions shoot me an email at info @ sensr.net

item.title: How to Setup The HooToo HT-IP006N With Cloud Recording
item.description:
HooToo outdoor model

The HooToo HT-IP006N is the outdoor camera model produced by HooToo, the company that made the camera I wrote about the other day. Like this other camera the HooToo HT-IP006N has a number of top of the line features and a very accessible UI. This one is more expensive than the last one coming in at $299. It is no small purchase but gets great reviews on amazon so it is definitely worth consideration. Of  course the best part about this camera is that it is compatible with Sensr.net. This tutorial will show you how to get your camera setup and recording to the cloud.

First you’ll need to setup your hardware. Just plug the camera into a power source and your router. Make sure you put your camera in a place where it will have the most effective line of sight. Once you’ve got your camera plugged in you are going to need to find it’s IP address. You can do this buy using their software or going through your router. I’ll show you how to go through your router.

I will show you how to do this on a mac (because I am writing from a mac) but it is also very easy to do from a PC (the PC process is outlined in this article). On my mac it is under system preferences>Network>Advanced…>TCP/IP. The page looks like this:

Once you have the IP address just enter it into your browser and it should bring you to a network access page. Everyone’s looks different depending on the make and model of their browser. Mine, for example, looks like this:

If you aren’t sure which device is new you can always unplug your camera then plug it back in to see which one disappears and comes back.

Step three: go to your camera’s network access page

Type this IP address into your browser and you will come to a page requesting a username and password. The username is admin and their is no password. After entering those you will come to this page:

Choose the one that matches your browser. Then you’ll come to a page that looks like this:

From this page you can control every part of the camera. Feel free to explore this when you have time and find out how to work all of you camera’s features. For now its onto set four.

Step four: get FTP credentials from Sensr.net

Now you are ready to setup stuff from the Sensr.net side of things. We will store all your recorded data in the cloud so you can access it from any device, anywhere. We have a number of different plans but the first week is always free so just set it up and give it a try. If you don’t like it you don’t need to continue to a payed plan. Log into your Sensr.net account click the Add Camera button. Once you login you’ll see a page like this: Next you’ll see a page like this where you can set the timezone for your camera, give it a name, and tell us the model.  Cameras default to private but you can make them public if you want to share them with the world. After that, we’ll generate some FTP credentials for your server. This generates a login for your  HooToo to where it can upload images via FTP. This tells your camera where to upload the images. The important information here is:

  1. FTP Server
  2. FTP User name
  3. FTP Password

Save these so we can add them to your camera later. 

Time for the fifth and final step…

Step five: tell you camera about your Sensr.net FTP credentials

Go back to your network access page. Click on other on the left menu than choose FTP settings. The page will look like this:

Copy and paste the credentials you got earlier and change the mode to passive. Change the upload interval to 1. Hit submit.

 Go back to the Sensr.net tab and it should look something like this:


Congratulations, now you’re done with the camera config. You’re camera is now on Sensr.net. We’ll archive all the motion events, giving you 30 days of archives, SMS and email alerts, guest access, and a whole lot more.  You can view the live stream on our website or in our apps.  No firewall configuration is needed.  No PC in the basement required.

If you have any problems, send email to info @ sensr.net and we’ll try to help you out!
